member.name: M:NsisIsXnaInstalled(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that XNA in the given version is installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of XNA is installed
member.remarks: This method asks for the DirectX version to check because the different versions can be installed side-by-side. If you developed a XNA 1.0 application and the user has installed XNA 2.0 but not XNA 1.0, your application will not work.

member.name: M:NsisIsWindowsInstallerInstalled(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that Windows Installer in the given version are installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of Windows Installer is installed

member.summary: Verifies that the operating system is at least the specified version
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the running operating system is of the specified version or newer

member.summary: Verifies that the XACT Libary in the given version is installed

member.name: M:NsisIsD3DXInstalled(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that the D3DX Libary in the given version is installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of the D3DX Library is installed
member.remarks: The version numbers that can be specified are the DirectX release dates, eg. "February 2005" will test whether the D3DX library from the February 2005 release of DirectX is installed. XNA Game Studio 1.0 developers will want to use "October 2006", as this is the version being targeted by XNA Game Studio Express 1.0 Refresh.

member.name: M:NsisIsDirectXInstalled(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that the DirectX Core Components in the given version are installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of the DirectX Core Components is installed
member.remarks: This method asks for the DirectX Core version to check because the different versions can be installed side-by-side. If you developed a DirectX 9.0 application and the user has installed DirectX 10.1 but not DirectX 9.0, your application will not work.

member.name: M:NsisIsDotNetInstalled(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that the .NET Framework in the given version is installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of the .NET Framework is installed
member.remarks: This method asks for the .NET Framework version to check because the different framework versions can be installed side-by-side. If you developed a .NET 2.0 application and the user has installed the .NET Framework 3.5 but not the .NET Framework 2.0, your application will not work.

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DotNet.IsDotNetFrameworkInstalled(Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DotNet.DotNetFrameworkVersions)
member.summary: Verifies that the .NET Framework in the given version is installed
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if the specified version of the .NET Framework is installed
member.remarks: This method asks for the .NET Framework version to check because the different framework versions can be installed side-by-side. If you developed a .NET 1.1 application and the user has installed the .NET Framework 2.0 but not the .NET Framework 1.1, your application will not work.

member.name: T:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DotNet.DotNetFrameworkVersions
member.summary: Known Versions of the .NET Framework

member.name: F:Framework_4_0_Full
member.summary: Version that is shipped with Visual Studio 2010

member.name: F:Framework_3_5_SP1
member.summary: Service release of the .NET Framework 3.5 including .NET 2.0 SP1

member.name: F:Framework_3_5
member.summary: Version that is shipped with Visual Studio 2008

member.name: F:Framework_3_0
member.summary: Extended .NET Framework 2.0 with libraries for WPF, WCF and WWF
member.remarks: Supported by Visual Studio 2005 with add-ons and in Visual Studio 2008

member.name: F:Framework_2_0_SP2
member.summary: Service release of the .NET Framework 2.0 including most patches
member.remarks: Fully backwards compatible to .NET 2.0, included in .NET 3.5 SP1

member.name: F:Framework_2_0_SP1
member.summary: Service release of the .NET Framework 2.0 including most patches
member.remarks: Fully backwards compatible to .NET 2.0

member.name: F:Framework_2_0
member.summary: New .NET Framework with generics as targeted by Visual Studio 2005
member.remarks: XNA projects and anything recently developed target this framework

member.name: F:Framework_1_1
member.summary: Upgraded version that was supported by Visual Studio .NET 2003
member.remarks: The most common version, also fully supported by Mono

member.name: F:Framework_1_0
member.summary: The framework as it was supported by the Visual Studio .NET
member.remarks: This version of the .NET Framework is completely obsolete now

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.Xna.IsXnaInstalled(Nuclex.Setup.Detector.Xna.XnaVersions)
member.summary: Verifies that the XNA Framework in the specified version is installed
member.param: XNA Framework version to check for
member.returns: True if the specified XNA Framework version is installed on the system

member.name: T:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.Xna.XnaVersions
member.summary: Known Versions of the XNA Framework

member.name: F:Xna_3_1
member.summary: XNA Framework 3.1 released in June 2009
member.remarks: Incremental update adding support for rendering XBox avatars in XNA, video playback and several enhancements to the audio pipeline.

member.name: F:Xna_3_0
member.summary: XNA Framework 3.0 released in October 2008
member.remarks: Updated release that introduct playtest mode, support for the Zune platform, integration into Visual Studio 2008 and visual C# 2008 Express and content compression for the XNA content pipeline.

member.name: F:Xna_2_0
member.summary: XNA Framework 2.0 released in December 2007
member.remarks: This release introduced some major changes to XNA by virtualizing the graphics device. Developers no lange have to handle lost device resources themselfes unless they're doing something funky with dynamic buffers.

member.name: F:Xna_1_0_Refresh
member.summary: XNA Framework refresh as published in April 2007
member.remarks: Refresh release of the original XNA Framework which added font rendering support and amongst others, relaxed some of the restrictions with render targets.

member.name: F:Xna_1_0
member.summary: Original release of the XNA Framework
member.remarks: The original XNA Framework release was missing font rendering support and imposed some more limitations on the developer than later releases. Theoretically applications built against the XNA Framework 1.0 Refresh could run on this framework too, if they don't make use of the new features.

member.name: M:NsisSupportsAtLeastShaderModel(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*)
member.summary: Verifies that the hardware supports at least the specified shader model
member.param: Version to be verified
member.returns: True if hardware is installed that supports the specified shader model
member.remarks: This function, of course, depends on a driver being installed that supports shaders. In some edge cases it might be that a system actually has a shader-capable graphics card but no supporting driver has been installed. Either use this check to warn the user or, if you decide to fail the setup, at least tell the user that it might be due to his graphics card drivers being outdated.

member.name: M:MsiCheckShaderModel(System.UInt32!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsLong)
member.summary: Checks whether hardware support for the specified shader model is available
member.param: MSI installation handle providing data about the running installation process
member.returns: ERROR_SUCCESS in case of success

member.param: Severity rating of the message
Number of this message in the error table
Message inserted in the error template's placeholder
Message box type (see MB_ enumeration values in Win32)
member.returns: The result of the message box. If this is IDCANCEL, the installation needs to terminate with ERROR_INSTALL_USEREXIT as soon as possible.

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.MsiHandle.ShowMessageBox(Nuclex.Setup.MessageSeverities,std.basic_string<System.Char,std.char_traits{System.Char},std.allocator<System.Char>>!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Shows a message box in the installer
member.param: Severity rating of the message
Formatted message that is shown to the user
Message box type (see MB_ enumeration values in Win32)
member.returns: The result of the message box. If this is IDCANCEL, the installation needs to terminate with ERROR_INSTALL_USEREXIT as soon as possible.

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.MsiHandle.LogMessage(Nuclex.Setup.LogSeverities,std.basic_string<System.Char,std.char_traits{System.Char},std.allocator<System.Char>>!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced)
member.summary: Writes a message into the installation log
member.param: Severity level of the message
Message that will be written to the installation log
member.returns: The result of the log publication. If this is IDCANCEL, the installation needs to terminate with ERROR_INSTALL_USEREXIT as soon as possible.

member.summary: Sets the specified property's value to be either true or false

Value to set the property to

member.summary: Sets a property in the running installation
member.param: Name of the property to set
Value to set the property to

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.MsiHandle.IsPropertyTrue(std.basic_string<System.Char,std.char_traits{System.Char},std.allocator<System.Char>>!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsImplicitlyDereferenced)
member.summary: Checks whether the specified property's value evaluates to true
member.param: Name of the property that will be checked
member.returns: True if the specified property's value evaluates to true
member.remarks: To avoid unneccessary complexity, only property values that evaluate to a numeric value other than 0 are considered being true. The string "true", for example, would be evaluated as meaning false.

member.summary: Retrieves a property stored in the running installation
member.param: Name of the property to retrieve
member.returns: The contents of the property with the specified name

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DirectX.IsD3DXLibraryInstalled(Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DirectX.DirectXLibraryVersions)
member.summary: Tests whether a specific version of the DirectX libraries is installed
member.param: Version of the DirectX libraries to check for
member.returns: True if the requested version is installed on the system
member.remarks: It is recommended to always use the latest DirectX SDK for developing new applications. Later versions of the DirectX libraries don't add any further hardware requirements, they merely provide extended functionality (such as new math operations in D3DX, for example).

member.name: M:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DirectX.IsDirectXCoreInstalled(Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DirectX.DirectXCoreVersions)
member.summary: Verifies that DirectX in the specified version is installed
member.param: DirectX version to check for
member.returns: True if the specified DirectX version is installed on the system
member.remarks: This function will only tell you wether the core components of DirectX are available. If your application uses D3DX (this includes XNA games), you will also have to check whether the D3DX version you need is installed.

member.name: T:Nuclex.Setup.Detector.DirectX.DirectXCoreVersions
member.summary: Known Versions of the DirectX Core Components

member.name: F:DirectXCore_10_1
member.summary: Updated DirectX 10 requiring second generation SM4.0 hardware

member.name: F:DirectXCore_10_0
member.summary: DirectX 10 is only available on the Windows Vista platform
member.remarks: This is a first generation unified shader (SM4.0) interface

member.name: F:DirectXCore_9_0
member.summary: Most common version of DirectX also used by XNA projects
member.remarks: If your game also uses the D3DX library (most games do, XNA games always), you will also have to check for the correct D3DX versions. Microsoft releases updated DirectX 9.0c variants every 2 or 3 months with new D3DX builds and most developers are unaware of that.
